tendons of the FDP, as illustrated here:      , and wrap around the lateral aspect of the MCP joints, anterior to their axis of rotation. 
Their course and insertion into the extensor expansion allow them to simultaneously flex the MCP joints and extend the PIP and DIP     .
The lumbricals of digits 2 and 3 are innervated by the median nerve, and those of digits 4 and 5 are innervated by the ulnar nerve. 
This distinction assists in the diagnosis of ulnar vs. median neuropathies, as you will soon learn.

The lumbricals act to flex the MCP joints and extend the PIP and DIP joints. 
They flex the MCP joints by inserting into the extensor expansions anterior to the fulcrum of the MCP joint (Figure B, blue arrow).
They extend the PIP and DIP joints because their pull is translated through the extensor expansions along the dorsal aspects of these joints (Figure B, yellow arrows).
This ability is critical in many delicate movements of the fingers, such as take place while writing.
